content.description: A large den in the ground near the base of this short tower provides the areas namesake; while drilling the summit anchors on the FA, the coyote pups in the den started yowling. Boulder to a ledge, clip the bolt, and move left to finish on an easier rib.
content.location: A short tower found just beyond the Superpecker from where you park.

content.description: The squat tower close to where you park. Boulder the face just right of the main groove and take the easy, loose ridge to the top.
content.protection: Pretty much a solo...easy after the initial bit. Single cold shut rap anchor.
content.location: Second tower from the left as viewed from where you park.

content.description: A very short tower with a slabby uphill face. No fixed anchors; carefully downclimb the route
content.protection: None, a solo up and down.
content.location: The small tower is located downhill from Yipping Coyote Tower.

content.description: This phallic monstrosity is the most elegant tower in the area. Move up and left past a pin over delicate, loose terrain to a flake, then up an easy runout face to the small summit. The route is visible in the photo.
content.protection: Fixed Pin, gear to 3", cold shuts on top.
content.location: This is the most striking phallic tower of the group. It's only a couple hundred feet from where you park, the route should be pretty obvious, look for a low fixed pin.

content.description: The "Siamese phallus" tower! A straightforward clean aid route up the obvious crack bisecting the spires west face. Has the best rock in the Coyote Rocks. The crack widens up top and can be free climbed to the ledge (single shut anchor here), where you can scamper carefully up hollow rock to the summit.
content.protection: Single set of cams to 3" and stoppers, aiders, single cold shut anchor--needles-style rap or lower leader and counterweight-anchor for second.
content.location: Obvious tower from where you parked. It's the rightmost tower in the overview photo.

content.description: Begin with thin crimping up the middle of the north face, clip the pin, delicately traverse left to a moderate rib with a crack, and then up the slabby, bolted face.
content.protection: 2 bolts, 1 fixed piton, small gear,  cold shut anchors.
content.location: A smaller outcropping about ¼ mile northwest of the Coyote Rocks. Park as for the Coyote Rocks, and hike across the open sage brush meadow to this solitary spire that is near the right (north) side of the Sheep Rocks. Named after the massive flocks that graze throughout the area in summer
